history.content:
EE C106A/B are pure robotics classes, if you're looking for those. The 106 series is very hands on (you get to program your own robots etc).

CS 188 to be honest isn't a super useful class. I would really just do 189. Yes it's theoretical, but take a light semester that semester. It'll be worth it. It's manageable if you just take 1 other light tech with it.

EE 120 is good and quite light with Babak. Don't know if it's useful for robotics though. I think you would have to take EE C128 (feedback control systems) to see how it actually relates to robotics. I would recommend EE C128 if you can get it with Fearing. 128 will teach you modern methods for control like state space and stuff (you've probably already seen this in 16B a little bit).

EE C106A/B are pure robotics classes, if you're looking for those. The 106 series very hands on (you get to program your own robots etc).

CS 188 to be honest isn't a super useful class. I would really just do 189. Yes it's theoretical, but take a light semester that semester. It'll be worth it. It's manageable if you just take 1 other light tech with it.

EE 120 is good and quite light with Babak.

children.subject:
It's very good domain knowledge. As an EE, you need to know how ICs work, as well as the basics of digital and analog design. If you have free electives, this would be the first class I would take. Think of it as the 162 of the EE side. It's not too conceptually hard generally, but it's very work intensive with hard labs and will teach you the basics of how modern electronics work.

However, that being said, it doesn't relate to ML/robotics in any really meaningful way.
What? Why not? I thought it was introductory AI course?

yeah, that's what I thought too. I was trying to see the opinion of those who wrote the student response though because they think that CS 188 isn't "a super useful class" and recommend taking 189 instead.
Compared to 189, it isn’t as useful for ML... That’s what I guessed the OP meant. To me, if you are ever gonna take 189, then make sure you take 188 before hand. It will be extremely helpful.
OP here. What I mean was, if you're gonna make ML/robotics your bread and butter, 188 isn't a good use of your time. It's more of a one and done overview class.
^ All the knowledge in 188 is incredibly important for robotics though. If you aren't going to take it you should definitely self study it thoroughly.
only if you are doing deep RL robotics, and even still its kinda arguable - in that case I would recommend 294-112 Deep RL

Motion planning and state estimation both heavily rely on the material covered in 188. Even if you choose not to take the class, you should self-study it and at some point have acquired knowledge equivalent to have taken the class.
188 isn't useful as an overview to the field of AI?
Worth noting that 128 isn't a purely electrical class - it's crosslisted as ME 134 so you get applications to both! I have heard good things about 131 though

I know this is late but 128 is the most fundamental class you can possibly take for controls (a huge part of robotics). 131 is a special topics course, but not taking 128 for robotics/controls is like not taking 61B for CS.
132 is nice but it's an easier version of 128 that doesn't cover as much (either 120 or 132 is a prereq for 128)

I think it depends on who is teaching. Yes, in theory 132 is a prerequisite for 128 but I know a lot of MechE undergrads who go straight to EE 221a or ME 231a because 128/134 would be too much overlap.

If you are going to take EE 128, you might want to take ME 131 instead, which covers similar material but might be more applicable to robotics (which deal with physical structures and less electrical)

history.content:
I was thinking of 

CS 188 (Intro to AI)

EE 120 (Signals)

EE 192 (Mechatronic Design Lab)

EE 149 (Embedded Systems) 

Any others? I don't really want to take CS189 (ML) at Berkeley because it seems very theoretical and also extremely challenging because of this (I'll take the online version from some other school or Coursera probably instead; I'll also try to focus on real experience from robotics clubs on internships relating to this area to get better at ML)
history.subject: Best UD EE/CS Courses for Robotics/AI?
